description.narrative:
Detta är ett tilläggsbeslut till 4/2018 och tilläggsbeslut 13/2020 och rör en förlängning av aktivitetsperioden av Sidas pågående kapacitetshöjande stöd till funktioner inom Kambodjas parlament. Kambodja inledde år 2004 en reform med syfte att stärka den offentliga finansiella styrningen (OFS). Reformen har finansierats av flera givare, däribland EU och Sida. Sedan 2011 har PIC fått svenskt stöd för att stödja genomförandet av sin verksamhet som bl.a. syftar till att bygga upp parlamentets analys- och utredningskapacitet. Det svenska stödet lämnas som ett kärnstöd till PIC:s nationella verksamhet.
Den senaste perioden som Sida stödjer med en total budget om MSEK 16,5 genomförs under perioden 2018-2020. Detta tilläggsbeslut innefattar en förlängning av aktivitetsperioden som egentligen ska avsultas 31 december 2020 men nu föreslås omfatta perioden fram till och med 31 mars 2021. Tilläggsbeslutet innefattar inget tillskott av medel.
Stödet under perioden 2018-2020 och även under förlängningen till 31 mars 2021 är ett budgetstöd till PIC:s Kambodja-verksamhet som bl.a. syftar till att stärka parlamentets förmåga att analysera statsbudgeten. Insatsen omfattar fortsatta utbildningsaktiviteter och fältbesök ute i landet, där parlamentarikernas kontakter med medborgarna står i fokus. Nätverkande och studiebesök vid andra parlament i regionen och/eller andra delar av världen ingår också men behöver sedan corona-pandemins start i början av 2020 ske online. PIC håller också på att omorganiseras för att även utöka sin regionala verksamhet till att omfatta liknande stöd som i Kambodja även till Myanmar, Laos och Vietnam. Detta kommer att ske genom att överföra PIC:s nuvarande verksamhet till en nystartad NGO som ska heta PCAsia fr o m 1 april 2021. En del av PIC:s verksamhet under förlängningen kommer att fokusera på denna omorganisation.

This is a supplementary decision to decision 4/2018 and supplementary decision 13/2020. It concerns an extension of the activity period of Sida's ongoing capacity-enhancing support for functions within Cambodia's parliament. In 2004, Cambodia launched a reform aimed at strengthening public financial management (OFS). The reform has been funded by several donors, including the EU and Sida. Since 2011, PIC has received Swedish financing to support the implementation of its activities, which e.g. aims to build up the Cambodian Parliament's analytical and investigative capacity. The Swedish support is provided as a core support to PIC's national operations.
The current Sida financing is SEK 16.5 million which is being implemented during the period 2018-2020. This additional decision includes an extension of the activity period from 31 December 2020, up to and including 31 March 2021. The supplementary decision does not include any additional funding.
The support during the period 2018-2020 and also during the extension to 31 March 2021 is a budget support to PIC's Cambodia operations which, among other things, aims to strengthen Parliament's ability to analyze the state budget. The initiative includes continued training activities and field visits out in the country, where the parliamentarians' contacts with the citizens are in focus. Networking and study visits to other parliaments in the region and / or other parts of the world are also included, but need to take place online since the start of the corona pandemic in early 2020. The PIC is also being reorganized to extend its regional operations to include similar support, through peer learning and exchange, to Myanmar, Laos and Vietnam. This will be done by transferring PIC's current operations to a newly started NGO called PCAsia from 1 April 2021. Part of PIC's operations during the extension will focus on this reorganization.

One of the core tasks of a parliament is to approve and oversee the executive branch of government’s budget and economic policies. This oversight is by nature technical, but parliamentarians may not have the background or resources necessary to effectively scrutinize fiscal and economic policy. To do so adequately, parliamentarians may find it useful to be supported by a non-partisan research service that specializes in the national budget and economy. This capacity is limited within the Cambodian Parliament— both the National Assembly (NA) and the Senate—and demand for such support is also limited. But by strengthening analytical capacity in the secretariats, it is expected that supply may drive demand for these services in the future by increasing knowledge about the value and importance of fiscal and economic oversight among parliamentarians themselves. The intervention financed under the PAT programme supports the establishment of a Parliamentary Budget Office (PBO) training programme. The name of the programme was changed during the implementation to Fiscal Analysis Capacity Training (FACT) programme. The intervention's intended outcomes are:1. Increased capacity of parliamentary staff to perform PBO-related tasks2. Enhanced understanding and knowledge of parliamentarians on budgetary matters3. An institutional foundation for a PBO in place. The main focus of the intervention is to train ten staff members from the Senate’s research department to conduct budget analysis. In parallel with the capacity building of this group of trainees, PIC is laying the foundations to institutionalize the expert knowledge of these trainees once their training is complete. The final decision on which institutional arrangement Cambodia will choose in relation to budget oversight will be a decision for the Parliament and is not under the control of the intervention.

description.narrative: The overall objective for the support was: “strengthened parliamentary oversight of the budget”. The support focused on enhancing parliamentary staffs’ understanding of the state budget, to build capacity to better analyse budgetary documents and to prepare for the set-up of a Parliamentary Budget office (PBO) in order to strengthen parliament’s oversight function.The focus of the intervention was to train ten staff members (five women and five men) from the Senate’s research department to conduct budget and fiscal analysis. In parallel with the capacity building of this group of trainees, PIC has also laid the foundation to institutionalise the expert knowledge of these trainees once their training is complete. Technical support was provided by experts with experience from the Swedish Parliamentary Research Services and the Ministry of Finance. All ten trainees successfully completed the courses and nine out of ten continued for the six-month extension of the program, passing all required additional training. The nine researchers remained within the Senate-managed PBO at the time this report was compiled.Dozens of training modules and formal classroom courses were delivered in the first and second year, and six were delivered in the final year. This number was higher than the target, both as the result of lower capacity of interns and the framework underestimating the breadth and depth of required budget office training. Mentoring sessions were constant, occurring daily, but several formal significant mentorship sessions were delivered roughly according to the output criteria. Over 30 research requests were fulfilled and over 20 fact-finding missions to provinces and overseas were organised. Parliamentarians embraced the research service, the research reports and briefings, and are eager to have the staff join the missions to assist in fact finding. Parliamentarians have reported that the reports were beneficial and have increased their understanding of budget issues and ability to study and oversee revenue raising and government spending programs.The number of requests by parliamentarians for PBO/FACT research products and services greatly exceed the original plans, with over 30 reports and over 20 outreach activities requested and supplied in the second and third year of the program. At the state budget briefings, the number of attendees was aligned with planned output, with approximately 20 parliamentarians and staffers attending the Commission 2 budget debrief presentations by PBO/FACT analysts. The number of linkages through study missions made with PBOs in the ASEAN region and elsewhere was in line with planned output, with a sister organisation agreement secured with the Philippines CPBRD, and Memorandum of Understanding signed with the IFSD in Canada, and relationships built with the PBOs in Canada and Sweden.Mission statements, policy documents, and procedural manuals exceeded the planned outputs, with between 6 to 12 each year. Meetings with stakeholders was roughly on par with planned output. The number of consultations with clients was similarly on target. The PBO/FACT program prepared all the institutional structures, protocols, and research tools required to establish a budget office. A gender responsive analysis was integrated into the curriculum where relevant, which provided the trainees with a theoretical and practical background of gender analysis. Courses on gender statistics and gender sensitive budgeting were delivered in 2018 and resulted in a gender report on the national budget in 2019. Practical observations of women access to public services and compilation of self-collected data were important inputs and also included in the program. It was clear that Gender Budgeting reports and reports involving gender perspectives of spending programmes are very important and have been produced as parts of briefing notes delivered to Cambodian Parliamentarians.
